Nonkungu and the 
 imbulu 
 
 Alan Kenyon and Viv Kenyon 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 Once upon a time there was a por
 couple. They had only one child, caled
 
 Nonkungu. They loved her very much.
 
 
 When she was old enough, her parents
 decided to send Nonkungu to stay with
 her rich Uncle Mtonyama. 
 
 
 Nonkungu's mother made special 
 clothes with ribon, butons and beads.
 
 She also made a beautiful necklace for
 her child. 
 
 
 Then Nonkungu set of for her uncle's
 vilage. 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 On her journey, Nonkungu came to a
 stream. She crosed the stream and met
 a girl wearing rags. The girl asked,
 
 "Where are you going?" 
 
 
 "I'm going to visit my Uncle Mtonyama,"
 replied Nonkungu. 
 "Wel, Mtonyama is my uncle, to! I am
 
 also on my way to visit him," said the girl.
 
 
 So they walked together. After a while,
 the girl said to Nonkungu, "Your clothes
 and necklace are beautiful. Please let me
 
 try them on." 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Nonkungu tok of her clothes and gave 
 
 them to the girl. When the girl tok of 
 her rags, Nonkungu saw that she had a 
 
 tail! 
 
 Nonkungu was afraid. She realised that 
 
 the girl was realy an imbulu. 
 
 
 They walked a litle further, and then 
 Nonkungu asked, "Please give me back 
 my clothes and beads." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The imbulu answered, "Let me wear them
 until we get to the next tre." And she
 
 pointed to a tre on a hil nearby.
 
 When they reached the tre, Nonkungu
 
 asked the imbulu, "Please give me back
 my clothes and beads." 
 
 
 "Just let me wear them until we get to
 that field," said the imbulu. And she
 
 pointed to a field on the next hil.
 Nonkungu was afraid, so she agred.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 At last they reached the field. Again
 
 Nonkungu asked the imbulu, "Please give
 me back my clothes and my beads."
 
 
 "Just let me wear them until we get to
 that hut where women are siting," said
 
 the imbulu. And she pointed to a hut in
 the distance. So they walked on.
 
 
 As they got near the hut, the imbulu
 pushed Nonkungu back and ran ahead.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The imbulu said to the women at the
 hut,"Lok at this girl wearing rags. She
 
 has ben folowing me al day. I wish she
 would go away." 
 
 
 The women turned to lok at Nonkungu.
 She was so frightened that she ran and
 
 hid in the kral. 
 
 
 Then the imbulu went to Uncle 
 Mtonyama's hut. She said swetly, "I am
 your niece, Nonkungu. My parents sent
 
 me to stay with you." 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Mtonyama and his family welcomed the
 girl. They were very kind to her.
 
 
 Por Nonkungu had to slep in the kral
 and share the dog's fod. During the day
 
 she hid in the fields and sang this song:
 "Oh misery me, misery me. 
 I was sent by my father and mother to
 
 stay with my Uncle Mtonyama. 
 On the way I met an imbulu and she tok
 
 my skirt and my beads. 
 Oh misery me, misery me." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day, Mtonyamaâ€™s eldest son was
 walking in the fields. He heard the
 
 strange and sad song. He didn't know
 who was singing, but when he got home,
 he told his father the words. 
 
 
 Mtonyama went into the fields. He heard
 
 the song, and loked until he found
 Nonkungu. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Nonkungu told her uncle everything that
 had hapened. Mtonyama tok her back
 
 to the vilage and hid her in a hut. He
 knew what he was going to do to catch
 the imbulu. 
 
 
 Mtonyama had heard that an imbulu's tail
 loves milk and that it can't go past milk
 
 without drinking some. 
 
 
 So he told his men to dig a hole and fil it
 with sour milk. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Then Mtonyama caled al the girls of the 
 vilage to take part in a jumping 
 
 competition. The imbulu was woried. 
 She did not want to jump over the hole. 
 
 
 The imbulu knew that her tail would be 
 thirsty for the sour milk. So she went into 
 
 a hut and tied her tail to her body as 
 tightly as she could. Then she tok her 
 place with the other girls. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One girl after another jumped over the 
 
 hole with the sour milk. At last it was the 
 imbulu's turn. She tried to jump high over 
 the hole, but her tail broke lose. 
 
 
 The imbulu's tail puled her down, down, 
 
 down into the sour milk. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 As the imbulu strugled in the milk, the 
 men quickly filed the hole with sand and 
 buried her. That was the end of the 
 
 imbulu. 
 
 Nonkungu stayed hapily with her uncle 
 
 for a long, long time. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12
